xhtml:p.xhtml:span: The string data type can contain characters, line feeds, carriage returns, and tab characters. The use cases are for any free form text entry or for any enumerated lists. Additionally the minimum and maximum lengths may be set and regular expression patterns may be specified.

notes.plain: The string data type can contain characters, line feeds, carriage returns, and tab characters. The use cases are for any free form text entry or for any enumerated lists. Additionally the minimum and maximum lengths may be set and regular expression patterns may be specified.
Valid Time Begin. If present this must be a valid datetime including timezone. It is used to indicate the beginning time that information is considered valid.

notes.plain: Valid Time End. If present this must be a valid date-time including timezone. It is used to indicate the ending time that information is considered valid or the time the information expired or will expire.

notes.plain: Descriptive name of this datatype model. Provides the semantic 'name' for the model. Replaces what would be XML element name, column name or class name in other modeling paradigms.

html.xhtml:p: Descriptive name of this datatype model. Provides the semantic 'name' for the model. Replaces what would be XML element name, column name or class name in other modeling paradigms.
The string value of the item.

notes.plain: The string value of the item.

html.xhtml:p: Optional indicator of the localised language in which this data-type is written. Only required when the language used here is different from the enclosing Entry.

notes.plain: Optional indicator of the localised language in which this data-type is written. Only required when the language used here is different from the enclosing Entry.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Items which represent boolean decisions, such as true/false or yes/no answers. Use for such data, it is important to devise the meanings (usually questions in subjective data) carefully, so that the only allowed results are in fact true or false.

The possible choices for True or False are enumerations in the CMC. The reference model defines 'true' and 'false' in a choice so only one or the other may be present in the instance data. Potential Misuse: The XdBooleanType should not be used as a replacement for enumerated types such as male/female, etc. Such values should be modeled as XdStrings with enumerations and may reference a controlled vocabulary. In any case the enumeration often has more than two values. The elements, 'true' and 'false' are contained in an xs:choice and only one or the other is instantiated in the instance data with its value coming from the enumerations defined in a CMC.

notes.plain:
Items which represent boolean decisions, such as true/false or yes/no answers. Use for such data, it is important to devise the meanings (usually questions in subjective data) carefully, so that the only allowed results are in fact true or false.
The possible choices for True or False are enumerations in the CMC. The reference model defines 'true' and 'false' in a choice so only one or the other may be present in the instance data. Potential Misuse: The XdBooleanType should not be used as a replacement for enumerated types such as male/female, etc. Such values should be modeled as XdStrings with enumerations and may reference a controlled vocabulary. In any case the enumeration often has more than two values. The elements, 'true' and 'false' are contained in an xs:choice and only one or the other is instantiated in the instance data with its value coming from the enumerations defined in a CMC.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Serves as the common ancestor of all eXtended data-types (Xd*) in S3Model.

notes.plain: Serves as the common ancestor of all eXtended data-types (Xd*) in S3Model.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Used to specify a Universal Resource Identifier.
Set the pattern facet to accommodate your needs in the DM.
Intended use is to provide a mechanism that can be used to link together Data
Models. The relation element allows for the use of a descriptive term for the link with an optional URI pointing to the source vocabulary.
In most usecases the modeler will define all three of these using the 'fixed' attribute.
Other usecases will have the 'relation' and 'relation-uri' elements fixed and the application will provide the 'link-value'.

notes.plain:
Used to specify a Universal Resource Identifier.
Set the pattern facet to accommodate your needs in the DM.
Intended use is to provide a mechanism that can be used to link together Data Models. The relation element allows for the use of a descriptive term for the link with an optional URI pointing to the source vocabulary.
In most usecases the modeler will define all three of these using the 'fixed' attribute.
Other usecases will have the 'relation' and 'relation-uri' elements fixed and the application will provide the 'link-value'.

Encapsulated data expressed as a parsable String. The internal model of the data item is not described in the MLHIM model in common with other encapsulated types, but in this case, the form of the data is assumed to be plaintext, rather than compressed or other types of large binary data.

Original size in bytes of unencoded encapsulated data. I.e. encodings such as base64, hexadecimal, etc. do not change the value of this element.

notes.plain: Original size in bytes of unencoded encapsulated data. I.e. encodings such as base64, hexadecimal, etc. do not change the value of this element.

html.xhtml:p: Name of character encoding scheme in which this value is encoded. Coded from the IANA charcater set table: http://www.iana.org/assignments/character-sets Unicode is the default assumption in S3Model, with UTF-8 being the assumed encoding. This attribute allows for variations from these assumptions.

notes.plain: Name of character encoding scheme in which this value is encoded. Coded from the IANA charcater set table: http://www.iana.org/assignments/character-sets Unicode is the default assumption in S3Model, with UTF-8 being the assumed encoding. This attribute allows for variations from these assumptions.

html.xhtml:p: Optional indicator of the localised language of the content. Typically remains optional in the CMC and used at runtime when the content is in a different language from the enclosing CMC.

notes.plain: Optional indicator of the localised language of the content. Typically remains optional in the CMC and used at runtime when the content is in a different language from the enclosing CMC.

html.xhtml:p: Name of the formalism or syntax used to inform an application regarding a candidate parser to use on the content. Examples might include: 'ATL', 'MOLA', 'QVT', 'GDL', 'GLIF', etc.

notes.plain: Name of the formalism or syntax used to inform an application regarding a candidate parser to use on the content. Examples might include: 'ATL', 'MOLA', 'QVT', 'GDL', 'GLIF', etc.

html.xhtml:p: Media (MIME) type of the original media-content w/o any compression. See IANA registered types: http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml

notes.plain: Media (MIME) type of the original media-content w/o any compression. See IANA registered types: http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml

html.xhtml:p: Compression/archiving mime-type. If this elements does not exist then it means there is no compression/archiving. For a list of common mime-types for compression/archiving see: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_archive_formats.

notes.plain: Compression/archiving mime-type. If this elements does not exist then it means there is no compression/archiving. For a list of common mime-types for compression/archiving see: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_archive_formats.

html.xhtml:p: Hash function result of the 'media-content'. There must be a corresponding hash function type listed for this to have any meaning. See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_hash_functions#Cryptographic_hash_functions

notes.plain: Hash function result of the 'media-content'. There must be a corresponding hash function type listed for this to have any meaning. See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_hash_functions#Cryptographic_hash_functions

html.xhtml:p: Hash function used to compute hash-result. See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_hash_functions#Cryptographic_hash_functions

notes.plain: Hash function used to compute hash-result. See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_hash_functions#Cryptographic_hash_functions

html.xhtml:p: Text to display in lieu of multimedia display or execution.

notes.plain: Text to display in lieu of multimedia display or execution.

html.xhtml:p: There are three possible ways to include the File content:
uri - URI reference to electronic information stored outside the record as a file, database entry etc, if supplied as a reference.
media-content - The content, if stored locally as binary content. The CMC modeler chooses either a uri, a binary-content element or a text-content element.
text-content - The content, if stored locally as text content. The CMC modeler chooses either a uri, a binary-content element or a text-content element.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: The modeler must delete two of the three options leaving only the chosen content method.

notes.plain:
There are three possible ways to include the File content:
uri - URI reference to electronic information stored outside the record as a file, database entry etc, if supplied as a reference.
media-content - The content, if stored locally as binary content. The CMC modeler chooses either a uri, a binary-content element or a text-content element.
text-content - The content, if stored locally as text content. The CMC modeler chooses either a uri, a binary-content element or a text-content element.
The modeler must delete two of the three options leaving only the chosen content method.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Abstract type defining the concept of ordered values, which includes ordinals as well as true quantities.
The implementations require the functions <
and is_strictly_comparable_to ('==').

notes.plain:
Abstract type defining the concept of ordered values, which includes ordinals as well as true quantities.
The implementations require the functions <, > and is_strictly_comparable_to ('==').

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Optional list of ReferenceRanges for this value in its particular measurement context.

notes.plain: Optional list of ReferenceRanges for this value in its particular measurement context.

html.xhtml:p: Optional normal status indicator of value with respect to normal range for this value. Often included by lab, even if the normal range itself is not included. Coded by ordinals in series HHH, HH, H, (nothing), L, LL, LLL, etc.

notes.plain: Optional normal status indicator of value with respect to normal range for this value. Often included by lab, even if the normal range itself is not included. Coded by ordinals in series HHH, HH, H, (nothing), L, LL, LLL, etc.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Models rankings and scores, e.g. pain, Apgar values, etc, where there is
a) implied ordering,
b) no implication that the distance between each value is constant, and
c) the total number of values is finite.

Note that although the term ‘ordinal’ in mathematics means natural numbers only, here any decimal is allowed, since negative and zero values are often used by medical and other professionals for values around a neutral point.
Also, decimal values are sometimes used such as 0.5 or .25
Examples of sets of ordinal values:
-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3 -- reflex response values
0, 1, 2 -- Apgar values
Also used for recording any clinical or other datum which is customarily recorded using symbolic values.
Examples: the results on a urinalysis strip, e.g. {neg, trace, +, ++, +++} are used for leukocytes, protein, nitrites, etc;
for non-haemolysed blood {neg, trace, moderate};
for haemolysed blood {neg, trace, small, moderate, large}.
Elements ordinal and symbol MUST have exactly the same number of enumerations.

notes.plain:
Models rankings and scores, e.g. pain, Apgar values, etc, where there is a) implied ordering, b) no implication that the distance between each value is constant, and c) the total number of values is finite.
Note that although the term ‘ordinal’ in mathematics means natural numbers only, here any decimal is allowed, since negative and zero values are often used by medical and other professionals for values around a neutral point.
Also, decimal values are sometimes used such as 0.5 or .25
Examples of sets of ordinal values:
-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3 -- reflex response values
0, 1, 2 -- Apgar values
Also used for recording any clinical or other datum which is customarily recorded using symbolic values.
Examples: the results on a urinalysis strip, e.g. {neg, trace, +, ++, +++} are used for leukocytes, protein, nitrites, etc;
for non-haemolysed blood {neg, trace, moderate};
for haemolysed blood {neg, trace, small, moderate, large}.
Elements ordinal and symbol MUST have exactly the same number of enumerations.

notes.plain: Optional normal status indicator of value with respect to normal range for this value. Often included by lab, even if the normal range itself is not included. Coded by ordinals in series HHH, HH, H, (nothing), L, LL, LLL, etc.

Value in ordered enumeration of values. The base integer is zero with any number of integer values used to order the symbols.
Example 1:
Example 2:
0 = Mild, 1 = Moderate, 2 = Severe

notes.plain:
Value in ordered enumeration of values. The base integer is zero with any number of integer values used to order the symbols.
Example 1: 0 = Trace, 1 = +, 2 = ++, 3 = +++, etc.
Example 2: 0 = Mild, 1 = Moderate, 2 = Severe

html.xhtml:p: Coded textual representation of this value in the enumeration, which may be strings made from “+” symbols, or other enumerations of terms such as “mild”, “moderate”, “severe”, or even the same number series as the values, e.g. “1”, “2”, “3”.

notes.plain: Coded textual representation of this value in the enumeration, which may be strings made from “+” symbols, or other enumerations of terms such as “mild”, “moderate”, “severe”, or even the same number series as the values, e.g. “1”, “2”, “3”.

Class defining the concept of date and time types. Must be constrained in CCDs to be one or more of the "dvtemporal-..." elements. This gives the modeller the ability to optionally allow partial dates at run time. Setting maxOccurs and minOccurs to zero cause the element to be prohibitied.
For example to allow a full date or only a month and year: Set all maxOccurs = 0 except dvtemporal-date and dvtemporal-month-year, leaves those as maxOccurs=1

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Class defining the concept of date and time types.
Must be constrained in CCDs to be one or more of the "dvtemporal-..." elements.
This gives the modeller the ability to optionally allow partial dates at run time. Setting maxOccurs and minOccurs to zero cause the element to be prohibitied.
For example to allow a full date or only a month and year:
Set all maxOccurs = 0 except dvtemporal-date and
dvtemporal-month-year, leaves those as maxOccurs=1

notes.plain: Longitude in decimal format. Value range -180.000000 to 180.000000.

html.xhtml:p: Longitude in decimal format. Value range -180.000000 to 180.000000.

notes.plain: Descriptive name of this datatype model. Provides the semantic 'name' for the model. Replaces what would be XML element name, column name or class name in other modeling paradigms.

html.xhtml:p: Descriptive name of this datatype model. Provides the semantic 'name' for the model. Replaces what would be XML element name, column name or class name in other modeling paradigms.

notes.plain: Optional list of ReferenceRanges for this value in its particular measurement context.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Optional list of ReferenceRanges for this value in its particular measurement context.

notes.plain: Optional normal status indicator of value with respect to normal range for this value. Often included by lab, even if the normal range itself is not included. Coded by ordinals in series HHH, HH, H, (nothing), L, LL, LLL, etc.

html.xhtml:p: Optional normal status indicator of value with respect to normal range for this value. Often included by lab, even if the normal range itself is not included. Coded by ordinals in series HHH, HH, H, (nothing), L, LL, LLL, etc.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Abstract type defining the concept of true quantified values, i.e. values which are not only ordered, but which have a precise magnitude.

notes.plain: Abstract type defining the concept of true quantified values, i.e. values which are not only ordered, but which have a precise magnitude.
Valid Time Begin. If present this must be a valid datetime including timezone. It is used to indicate the beginning time that information is considered valid.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Valid Time Begin. If present this must be a valid datetime including timezone. It is used to indicate the beginning time that information is considered valid.

notes.plain: Valid Time End. If present this must be a valid date-time including timezone. It is used to indicate the ending time that information is considered valid or the time the information expired or will expire.

html.xhtml:p: Valid Time End. If present this must be a valid date-time including timezone. It is used to indicate the ending time that information is considered valid or the time the information expired or will expire.

notes.plain: Time Recorded. If present this must be a valid date-time stamp. It is used to indicate the the actual date and time the data was recorded.

html.xhtml:p: Time Recorded. If present this must be a valid date-time stamp. It is used to indicate the the actual date and time the data was recorded.

notes.plain: Time Modified. If present this must be a valid date-time stamp. It is used to indicate the the actual date and time the data was last changed.

html.xhtml:p: Time Modified. If present this must be a valid date-time stamp. It is used to indicate the the actual date and time the data was last changed.

notes.plain: Descriptive name of this datatype model. Provides the semantic 'name' for the model. Replaces what would be XML element name, column name or class name in other modeling paradigms.

notes.plain: Optional list of ReferenceRanges for this value in its particular measurement context.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Optional list of ReferenceRanges for this value in its particular measurement context.

notes.plain: Optional normal status indicator of value with respect to normal range for this value. Often included by lab, even if the normal range itself is not included. Coded by ordinals in series HHH, HH, H, (nothing), L, LL, LLL, etc.

html.xhtml:p: Optional normal status indicator of value with respect to normal range for this value. Often included by lab, even if the normal range itself is not included. Coded by ordinals in series HHH, HH, H, (nothing), L, LL, LLL, etc.
Optional status of magnitude.
The implementation will select from the set of options:
"equal"
"less_than"
"greater_than"
"less_than_or_equal"
"greater_than_or_equal"
"approximate"
to indicate when there may or may not be uncertainty in the result.

notes.plain:
Optional status of magnitude.
The implementation will select from the set of options:
"equal" "less_than" "greater_than" "less_than_or_equal" "greater_than_or_equal" "approximate"
to indicate when there may or may not be uncertainty in the result.

html.xhtml:p: Error margin of measurement, indicating error in the recording method or instrument (+/- %). A logical value of 0 indicates 100% accuracy, i.e. no error.

notes.plain: Error margin of measurement, indicating error in the recording method or instrument (+/- %). A logical value of 0 indicates 100% accuracy, i.e. no error.

Countable quantities.
Used for countable types such as pregnancies and steps (taken by a physiotherapy patient), number of cigarettes smoked in a day, etc.
Misuse:Not used for amounts of physical entities (which all have standardized units)

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Countable quantities.
Used for countable types such as pregnancies and steps (taken by a physiotherapy patient), number of cigarettes smoked in a day, etc.
Misuse:
Not used for amounts of physical entities (which all have standardized
units)
Quantitified type representing “scientific” quantities, i.e. quantities expressed as a magnitude and units.
Can also be used for time durations, where it is more convenient to treat these as simply a number of individual seconds, minutes, hours, days, months, years, etc.

notes.plain:
Quantitified type representing “scientific” quantities, i.e. quantities expressed as a magnitude and units.
Can also be used for time durations, where it is more convenient to treat these as simply a number of individual seconds, minutes, hours, days, months, years, etc.

Models a ratio of values, i.e. where the numerator and denominator are both pure numbers. Used for recording generic ratios that can not be cathegorized as rates or proportions, such as titers (e.g. 1:128), concentration ratios, e.g. Na:K (unitary denominator), albumin:creatinine ratio, even when presented as percentages, e.g. red cell distribution width (RDW). Should not be used to represent things like blood pressure which are often written using a ‘/’ character, giving the misleading impression that the item is a ratio, when in fact it is a structured value. Similarly, visual acuity, often written as (e.g.) “6/24” in clinical notes is not a ratio but an ordinal (which includes non-numeric symbols like CF = count fingers etc). Should not be used for formulations. Rates and Proportions should use the DvRatio children classes, respectively DvRate and DvProportion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Models a ratio of values, i.e. where the numerator and denominator are both pure numbers. Used for recording generic ratios that can not be cathegorized as rates or proportions, such as titers (e.g. 1:128), concentration ratios, e.g. Na:K (unitary denominator), albumin:creatinine ratio, even when presented as percentages, e.g. red cell distribution width (RDW). Should not be used to represent things like blood pressure which are often written using a ‘/’ character, giving the misleading impression that the item is a ratio, when in fact it is a structured value. Similarly, visual acuity, often written as (e.g.) “6/24” in clinical notes is not a ratio but an ordinal (which includes non-numeric symbols like CF = count fingers etc).
Should not be used for formulations.
Rates and Proportions should use the DvRatio children classes, respectively DvRate and DvProportion.

notes.plain:
Generic class defining an interval (i.e. range) of a comparable type. An interval is a contiguous subrange of a comparable base type.
Used to define intervals of dates, times, quantities Whose units match and datatypes are the same and are ordered.
If the implementation technology has a concept of intervals AND the technology provides for multiple inheritance, then this class may inherit directly from it.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Generic class defining an interval (i.e. range) of a comparable type. An interval is
a contiguous subrange of a comparable base type.
Used to define intervals of dates, times, quantities Whose units match and datatypes are the same and are
ordered
If the implementation technology has a concept of intervals AND the technology provides for multiple inheritance, then this class may inherit directly from it.

notes.plain:
Defines a named range to be associated with any ORDERED datum. Each such range is particular to the patient and context, e.g. sex, age, and any other factor which affects ranges.
May be used to represent normal, therapeutic, dangerous, critical etc ranges.

xhtml:p.xhtml:span: Defines a named range to be associated with any ORDERED datum. Each such
range is particular to the patient and context, e.g. sex, age, and any other factor
which affects ranges.
May be used to represent normal, therapeutic, dangerous, critical etc ranges.
